t: Job 20
Zophar Speaks
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite replied:
This*pn is why my unsettling thoughts compel me to answer, because*ln I am upset!
I*ln have heard a rebuke that insults me, and*ln my understanding makes me reply.
Don’t*pn you know that ever since antiquity, from*ln the time a human was placed on earth,
the*ln joy of the wicked has been brief and*ln the happiness of the godless has lasted only a moment?
Though*ln his arrogance reaches heaven, and*ln his head touches the clouds,
he*ln will vanish forever like his own dung. Those*ln who know him will ask, “Where is he?”
He*ln will fly away like a dream and never be found; he*ln will be chased away like a vision in the night.
The*ln eye that saw him will see him no more, and*ln his household will no longer see him.
His*ln children will beg from the poor, for*ln his own hands must give back his wealth.
His*ln frame may be full of youthful vigor, but*ln it will lie down with him in dust.
Though*pn evil tastes sweet in his mouth and*ln he conceals it under his tongue,
though*ln he cherishes it and will not let it go but*ln keeps it in his mouth,
yet*ln the food in his stomach turns into*ln cobras’ venom inside him.
He*ln swallows wealth but must vomit it up; God*ln will force it from his stomach.
He*ln will suck the poison of cobras; a*ln viper’s fangs will kill him.
He*ln will not enjoy the streams, the*ln rivers flowing with honey and curds.
He*ln must return the fruit of his labor without consuming it; he*ln doesn’t enjoy the profits from his trading.
For*ln he oppressed and abandoned the poor; he*ln seized a house he did not build.
Because*pn his appetite is never satisfied, he*ln does not let anything he desires escape.
Nothing*ln is left for him to consume; therefore,*ln his prosperity will not last.
At*ln the height of his success distress will come to him; the*ln full weight of misery will crush him.
When*ln he fills his stomach, God*ln will send his burning anger against him, raining*ln it down on him while he is eating.
If*ln he flees from an iron weapon, an*ln arrow from a bronze bow will pierce him.
He*ln pulls it out of his back, the*ln flashing tip out of his liver. Terrors*ln come over him.
Total*ln darkness is reserved for his treasures. A*ln fire unfanned by human hands will consume him; it*ln will feed on what is left in his tent.
The*ln heavens will expose his iniquity, and*ln the earth will rise up against him.
The*ln possessions in his house will be removed, flowing*ln away on the day of God’s anger.
This*ln is the wicked person’s lot from God, the*ln inheritance God ordained for him.
